Hello, I am trying to merge the proof of "a group is profinite iff it is the projective limit of finite group with discrete topology". This PR depend on PR #16648 and would finish proving the "if" side. But for the other side I have some questions :
1 : I defined the structure of closed subgroup and open normal subgroup, is it an appropriate place to put it on the side of OpenSubgroup.lean?
2 : There are additional lemmas for compact topological group, to prove that there is always a open subgroup in a clopen neihborhood of 1, it needs to import OpenSubgroup.lean, so where should I put it?
Thank you

The file OpenSubgroup.lean is only 366 lines for the time being, I think that putting closed subgroup and open normal ones there is OK. Perhaps also the lemmas you mention in 2. can go there, apart from the "purely topological" ones (if you have any) that probably need nothing about topological groups and can go somewhere else in the purely topological library.
Thank you. So do I need to rename the file OpenSUbgroup after putting them all in iit? What can be an appropriate name?(I didn't think of any good name that can describe them all)

I think OpenSubgroup is still ok (provided you change the description at the beginning of the files inserting the new declarations), but let me ping @Johan Commelin who is the author of the original file.
I think it's fine to keep the name like this for now.
Maybe it could be renamed... just Subgroup.lean? Or something else? But that could also be done in a follow-up PR.
Yes, I also though that Subgroup is enough, since at any rate we're in the topology folder.

files merged as suggested, but is it ok to make a dependent PR to add the theorems I mentioned in probelm 2 because they are in the same file (although the content doesn't rely on each other, these add together makes the file almost reach 900 lines.)
Yes, dependent PRs are totally fine. See the PR commit message template for instructions on how to mark on PR as dependent on another.

Just to make it clear (and I am writing this under @Johan Commelin 's control, so I might be very wrong but I hope that what follows will help): if you have a PR with 100 (say) file changes, what you can do is open several PR's, where the first just contains (say) 10 changes, the second contains 20 changes but 10 of which are precisely the 10 in the first PR, the third contains 30 changes but 20 of which have already been considered, and so on...

You end up with 10 PR's with "just" 10 changes each, and in each one of those you mention the dependencies. The strategy for you is to keep on mergeing master on all the PR's, so that once the nth is merged, the n+1th really only has its new 10 changes that appear in the diff against master.

This might be a bit painful, but

  1. I think this is the normal way to go; and
  2. Some old pencil+paper to keep track of PR numbers+PR contain, will do.

(In this case, but only if you're already fairly confident with git, using rebase so that there's only one commit added per PR might be useful. If you don't know what I mean by that, stick to merging.)
